animalOfTheDay.name: rottweiler
facts: Rottweilers are descended from Roman war dogs and were used to herd cattle.
Despite their tough appearance, they are affectionate with their families.
They are powerfully built dogs with a natural guarding instinct.
Rottweilers were one of the first police dogs and are still used in K-9 units today.

calendar.name: rattlesnake
facts: Rattlesnakes have a rattle made of keratin segments that add a new one each time they shed.
They are pit vipers, with heat-sensing organs to detect warm-blooded prey.
Rattlesnakes give live birth, unlike many snakes that lay eggs.
They can control the amount of venom injected, sometimes delivering 'dry' bites as warnings.

calendar.name: raven
facts: In mythology, they are often symbols of wisdom or trickery.
Ravens play games, such as sliding down snowbanks or dropping sticks in flight to catch them.
They can mimic human speech and other sounds, though not as well as parrots.
Ravens are among the smartest birds, capable of problem-solving and tool use.

calendar.name: red panda
facts: Red pandas are not closely related to giant pandas but share a bamboo-heavy diet.
They have a false thumb, an extended wrist bone, to help grip bamboo.
They are endangered, with fewer than 10,000 left in the wild due to habitat loss.
Red pandas are solitary and mark territory with scent glands on their feet.

calendar.name: rhinoceros
facts: Rhino horns are made of keratin, the same protein as human hair and nails.
Rhinos have thick skin, but it can be sensitive to sunburn and insect bites, leading them to wallow in mud.
All five rhino species are threatened by poaching, with three critically endangered.
They communicate through grunts, snorts, and even infrasound below human hearing.

calendar.name: robin
facts: They are territorial and will aggressively defend their feeding areas in winter.
Robins sing year-round, with males using song to establish territory and attract mates.
Robins are known for their red breasts, which are brighter in males during breeding season.
They are one of the first birds to sing at dawn, earning them the nickname 'the early bird.'

calendar.name: rook
facts: They are among the most intelligent birds and can use simple tools.
They form lifelong pair bonds and often stay with the same mate for life.
Rooks have pale, featherless faces that distinguish them from other crows.
Rooks are highly social corvids that nest in large colonies called rookeries.

calendar.name: rottweiler
facts: Despite their tough appearance, they are affectionate with their families.
Rottweilers were one of the first police dogs and are still used in K-9 units today.
They are powerfully built dogs with a natural guarding instinct.
Rottweilers are descended from Roman war dogs and were used to herd cattle.

randomAnimals.name: water buffalo
facts: Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.

randomAnimals.name: water monitor
facts: They are very intelligent reptiles that can open locks and learn from humans.
The water monitor is a large lizard from Asia, an excellent swimmer and diver, capable of staying underwater for a long time.
They can reach up to 3 meters (10 feet) in length and are often found near water.
They are predators, feeding on fish, birds, small mammals, eggs, and carrion.

randomAnimals.name: snow leopard
facts: Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.
They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.
